content: Strategy Wikipedia Definition.
title: strategy

content: StrategyÂ (fromÂ GreekÂ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î·Î³Î¯Î±Â stratÄ“gia, "art of troop leader; office of general, command, generalship"[1]) is a generalÂ planÂ to achieve one or more long-term or overallÂ goalsÂ under conditions ofÂ uncertainty. In the sense of the "artÂ of the general", which included several subsets of skills includingÂ military tactics,Â siegecraft,Â logisticsÂ etc., the term came into use in the 6th century C.E. inÂ Eastern RomanÂ terminology, and was translated into WesternÂ vernacular languagesÂ only in the 18th century. From then until the 20th century, the word "strategy" came to denote "a comprehensive way to try to pursue political ends, including the threat or actual use of force, in a dialectic of wills" in aÂ military conflict, in which both adversaries interact.[2] Strategy is important because the resources available to achieve goals are usually limited. Strategy generally involves setting goals and priorities, determining actions to achieve the goals, and mobilizing resources to execute the actions.[2]A strategy describes how the ends (goals) will be achieved by the means (resources).[3]Â Strategy can be intended or can emerge as a pattern of activity as the organization adapts to its environment or competes.[2]Â It involves activities such asÂ strategic planningÂ andÂ strategic thinking.[4] Henry MintzbergÂ fromÂ McGill UniversityÂ defined strategy as a pattern in a stream of decisions to contrast with a view of strategy as planning,[5]Â while Henrik von Scheel defines the essence of strategy as the activities to deliver a unique mix of value â€“ choosing to perform activities differently or to perform different activities than rivals.[6]Â whileÂ Max McKeownÂ (2011) argues that "strategy is about shaping theÂ future" and is the human attempt to get to "desirable ends with available means". Dr.Â Vladimir KvintÂ defines strategy as "a system of finding, formulating, and developing a doctrine that will ensure long-term success if followed faithfully."[7]Â Complexity theorists define strategy as the unfolding of the internal and external aspects of the organization that results in actions in a socio-economic context.[8][9][10]
title: strategy

content: Components ProfessorÂ Richard P. RumeltÂ described strategy as a type of problem solving in 2011. He wrote that good strategy has an underlying structure he called aÂ kernel. The kernel has three parts: 1) AÂ diagnosisÂ that defines or explains the nature of the challenge; 2) AÂ guiding policyÂ for dealing with the challenge; and 3) CoherentÂ actionsÂ designed to carry out the guiding policy.[11]Â PresidentÂ KennedyÂ illustrated these three elements of strategy in hisÂ Cuban Missile CrisisÂ Address to the Nation of 22 October 1962: Diagnosis: "This Government, as promised, has maintained the closest surveillance of the Soviet military buildup on the island of Cuba. Within the past week, unmistakable evidence has established the fact that a series of offensive missile sites are now in preparation on that imprisoned island. The purpose of these bases can be none other than to provide aÂ nuclearÂ strike capability against the Western Hemisphere." Guiding Policy: "Our unswerving objective, therefore, must be to prevent the use of these missiles against this or any other country, and to secure their withdrawal or elimination from the Western Hemisphere." Action Plans: First among seven numbered steps was the following: "To halt this offensive buildup a strict quarantine on all offensive military equipment under shipment to Cuba is being initiated. All ships of any kind bound for Cuba from whatever nation or port will, if found to contain cargoes of offensive weapons, be turned back."[12] Rumelt wrote in 2011 that three important aspects of strategy include "premeditation, the anticipation of others' behavior, and the purposeful design of coordinated actions." He described strategy as solving a design problem, with trade-offs among various elements that must be arranged, adjusted and coordinated, rather than a plan or choice.[11]
title: strategy

content: Formulation and implementation Strategy typically involves two major processes:Â formulationÂ andÂ implementation.Â FormulationÂ involves analyzing the environment or situation, making a diagnosis, and developing guiding policies. It includes such activities asÂ strategic planningÂ andÂ strategic thinking.Â ImplementationÂ refers to the action plans taken to achieve the goals established by the guiding policy.[4][11] Bruce HendersonÂ wrote in 1981 that: "Strategy depends upon the ability to foresee future consequences of present initiatives." He wrote that the basic requirements for strategy development include, among other factors: 1) extensive knowledge about the environment, market and competitors; 2) ability to examine this knowledge as an interactive dynamic system; and 3) the imagination and logic to choose between specific alternatives. Henderson wrote that strategy was valuable because of: "finite resources, uncertainty about an adversary's capability and intentions; the irreversible commitment of resources; necessity of coordinating action over time and distance; uncertainty about control of the initiative; and the nature of adversaries' mutual perceptions of each other."[13]
title: strategy

content: Military theory Main article:Â Military strategy Subordinating the political point of view to the military would be absurd, for it is policy that has created warâ€¦Policy is the guiding intelligence, and war only the instrument, not vice-versa. On WarÂ byÂ Carl von Clausewitz In military theory, strategy is "the utilization during both peace and war, of all of the nation's forces, through large scale, long-range planning and development, to ensure security and victory" (Random House Dictionary).[5] The father of Western modernÂ strategic study,Â Carl von Clausewitz, defined military strategy as "the employment of battles to gain the end of war."Â B. H. Liddell Hart's definition put less emphasis on battles, defining strategy as "the art of distributing and applying military means to fulfill the ends of policy".[14]Â Hence, both gave the pre-eminence to political aims over military goals. U.S. Naval War College instructor Andrew Wilson defined strategy as the "process by which political purpose is translated into military action."[15]Â Lawrence FreedmanÂ defined strategy as the "art of creating power."[16] EasternÂ militaryÂ philosophy dates back much further, with examples such asÂ The Art of WarÂ byÂ Sun TzuÂ dated around 500 B.C.[17]
title: strategy

content: Management theory Main article:Â Strategic management The essence of formulating competitive strategy is relating a company to its environment. Michael Porter^[18]^ Modern business strategy emerged as a field of study and practice in the 1960s; prior to that time, the words "strategy" and "competition" rarely appeared in the most prominent management literature.[19][20]Â Alfred ChandlerÂ wrote in 1962 that: "Strategy is theÂ determinationÂ of the basic long-term goals of anÂ enterprise, and the adoption of courses of action and the allocation of resources necessary for carrying out these goals."[21]Â Michael PorterÂ defined strategy in 1980 as the "...broad formula for how a business is going to compete, what its goals should be, and what policies will be needed to carry out those goals" and the "...combination of theÂ endsÂ (goals) for which the firm is striving and theÂ meansÂ (policies) by which it is seeking to get there."[18] Henry MintzbergÂ described five definitions of strategy in 1998: Strategy as plan â€“ a directed course of action to achieve anÂ intendedÂ set of goals; similar to the strategic planning concept; Strategy as pattern â€“ a consistent pattern of past behavior, with a strategyÂ realizedÂ over time rather than planned orÂ intended. Where the realized pattern was different from the intent, he referred to the strategy asÂ emergent; Strategy as position â€“ locating brands, products, or companies within the market, based on the conceptual framework of consumers or other stakeholders; a strategy determined primarily by factors outside the firm; Strategy as ploy â€“ a specific maneuver intended to outwit a competitor; and Strategy as perspective â€“ executing strategy based on a "theory of the business" or natural extension of the mindset or ideological perspective of the organization.[22]
title: strategy

content: Strategies InÂ game theory, aÂ strategyÂ refers to the rules that aÂ playerÂ uses to choose between the available actionable options. Every player in aÂ non-trivial gameÂ has a set of possible strategies to use when choosing what moves to make. A strategy may recursivelyÂ look aheadÂ and consider what actions can happen in each contingent state of the gameâ€”e.g. if the player takes action 1, then that presents the opponent with a certain situation, which might be good or bad, whereas if the player takes action 2 then the opponents will be presented with a different situation, and in each case the choices they make will determine their own future situation. Strategies in game theory may beÂ random (mixed)Â or deterministic (pure). Pure strategies can be thought of as a special case of mixed strategies, in which onlyÂ probabilitiesÂ 0 or 1 are assigned to actions. Strategy based games generally require a player to think through a sequence of solutions to determine the best way to defeat the opponent.
title: strategy

content: Counterterrorism Strategy BecauseÂ counterterrorismÂ involves the synchronized efforts of numerous competing bureaucratic entities, national governments frequently create overarching counterterrorism strategies at the national level.[23]Â A national counterterrorism strategy is a government's plan to use the instruments of national power to neutralize terrorists, their organizations, and their networks in order to render them incapable of using violence to instill fear and to coerce the government or its citizens to react in accordance with the terrorists' goals.[23]Â The United States has had several such strategies in the past, including theÂ United States National Strategy for CounterterrorismÂ (2018);[24]Â the Obama-eraÂ National Strategy for CounterterrorismÂ (2011); and theÂ National Strategy for Combatting TerrorismÂ (2003). There have also been a number of ancillary or supporting plans, such as the 2014Â Strategy to Counter the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, and the 2016Â Strategic Implementation Plan for Empowering Local Partners to Prevent Violent Extremism in the United States.[23]Â Similarly, the United Kingdom's counterterrorism strategy,Â CONTEST, seeks "to reduce the risk to the UK and its citizens and interests overseas from terrorism, so that people can go about their lives freely and with confidence."[25] Link <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategy>
title: strategy

title: Emoji Support

content: Emoji can be enabled in a Hugo project in a number of ways. The emojify function can be called directly in templates or Inline Shortcodes. To enable emoji globally, set enableEmoji to true in your site configuration and then you can type emoji shorthand codes directly in content files. These begin and end with a colon and include the code of an emoji: Gone camping! :tent: Be back soon. That is so funny! :joy: The rendered output looks like this: Gone camping! â›º Be back soon.
